claim: America has fewer obese people than Australia.

supporting.text: According to the World Health Organization, the obesity rate in the United States is higher than in Australia.

attacks.text: According to the World Health Organization, the obesity rate in the United States is higher than in Australia.
The WHO data might not account for recent public health interventions in the U.S. that have reduced obesity rates.
Recent studies from the CDC show that U.S. obesity rates have plateaued or declined in certain demographics, while Australia's rates continue to rise.
The WHO's methodology may differ from national surveys, leading to discrepancies in reported obesity rates.
National health surveys in both countries align with WHO findings, confirming higher obesity rates in the U.S.

supporting.text: Statistical data from the OECD shows that the prevalence of obesity in the US exceeds that of Australia.

attacks.text: Statistical data from the OECD shows that the prevalence of obesity in the US exceeds that of Australia.
The OECD data may not account for differences in measurement methodologies between the US and Australia.
OECD standards for obesity measurement are internationally recognized and consistently applied across member countries.
Recent trends or localized data within the US might show lower obesity rates than Australia in specific regions.
National averages are more representative than regional data for comparing obesity prevalence between countries.

supporting.text: National health surveys indicate that a larger percentage of the American population is classified as obese compared to Australia.

attacks.text: National health surveys indicate that a larger percentage of the American population is classified as obese compared to Australia.
The methodology of national health surveys may differ between the two countries, leading to inconsistent obesity classifications.
Standardized international health metrics are often used to ensure comparability between national health surveys.
Cultural differences in self-reporting body weight may skew the survey results.
Many national health surveys use measured weight and height rather than self-reported data to determine obesity rates.

supporting.text: The CDC and Australian health authorities report higher obesity rates in the US than in Australia.

attacks.text: The CDC and Australian health authorities report higher obesity rates in the US than in Australia.
The data may not account for differences in measurement methodologies between the US and Australia.
Both the CDC and Australian health authorities follow standardized WHO guidelines for obesity measurement, ensuring comparability.
The reported rates might not reflect recent trends, as obesity rates can change over time.
Both the CDC and Australian health authorities regularly update their obesity statistics, ensuring current data is used.
